title: Cyclist magazine issue 164: on sale now
content:
Cyclist
Cyclist magazine issue 164: on sale now

Cyclist magazine Issue 164, July 2025, is on sale now. Subscribe to Cyclist here or buy issue 164 at the Cyclist Shop

The 2025 Giro d’Italia is in its final week, and the action is hotting up nicely in the hunt for the maglia rosa. Much of that is down to a race route that has saved its biggest tests for last, with a final-week stage menu loaded with high mountain passes and summit finishes.

Highlights include such feared names as the Mortirolo and Colle delle Finestre, but one climb the peloton will be relieved not to have to face this year is Monte Zoncolan. One of a small number of Grand Tour ascents with a legitimate claim to the title of the hardest climb in cycling, the Zoncolan is a brutal test of both mind and muscle, and in its seven Giro appearances since its first inclusion in 2003, the Zoncolan has brought some of the biggest names in the business to their knees.

But where the pros fear to tread, Cyclist magazine doesn’t, and our July 2025 issue – available today on the newsstands and from the Cyclist Shop – zeroes in on northeast Italy for a first-hand taste of just what makes the Zoncolan such a fearsome ascent.

Whoever ends up as Giro winner this Sunday, the focus will then swiftly move to cycling’s biggest race, the Tour de France, which gets underway in Lille on 5th July. The Tour is a race like no other, yet for all the great Tour champions France has produced down the years, this year marks 40 years since the last time a Frenchman topped the podium in Paris. This issue we take a closer look at why French riders have found success in their own Grand Tour so elusive, and who among the latest crop of young hopefuls has a chance of ending the drought.

One man who’ll be as happy as anyone to see a new home-grown Tour winner emerge is French UCI president David Lappartient. We catch up with the boss of cycling’s governing body to find out how he keeps on top of the unique challenge of steering the global sport through a seemingly endless list of challenges.

Speaking of challenges, someone who has faced more than his fair share is Colin Clews, the founder of the CiCLE Classic, Britain’s only UCI-level one-day road race. One year on from the heartache of having to cancel the race due to heavy flooding, he talks about what makes the event so special and how proud he is to have seen the race bounce back stronger than ever in April for its 20th running.

Then we’re off to the New Forest with three of the latest crop of all-road bikes for what turns out to be an intense debate on just what the term ‘all-road’ actually means, and what the reasons are for buying one.

Also in the July 2025 issue, we take a first look at the new Cannondale Synapse, examine the latest crop of electric tyre inflators, look back on the women’s Classics season through the lens of a pair of leading pro photographers and test out new bikes from BMC, Guava and Rondo.

There’s plenty more to enjoy in the latest issue too, so pick up your copy on newsstands or at the Cyclist Shop or get a Cyclist magazine subscription to have every issue delivered free, straight to your door.

There are three levels of Cyclist subscriptions available. For access to the Cyclist Rides online archive, prices start at £19.95 for six-months. For the Cyclist digital package, which includes the digital version of Cyclist magazine plus Cyclist Rides, prices start at £21.95 for six-months. For the full Cyclist membership, which includes Cyclist print magazine, the digital version of Cyclist, and Cyclist Rides, with prices starting at £37.95 for six-months.

A one-year Cyclist membership comes with a free gift and costs £75.95 if you choose the direct debit option, which will automatically renew, or £87.95 without direct debit.

A Cyclist membership or digital subscription also currently come with 60 days of free Laka bike insurance, plus discounted tickets to Cyclist Track Days and complementary tickets to Cycling Electric Demo Days.
